title: Cal City

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. A copy of all agreements, contracts, performance work statements, requests for proposal, and clarifications between ICE and CoreCivic allowing the company to reopen and operate what is now known as the California City Immigration Processing Center in California City California. Some or all of these arrangements may fall within Contract ID 70CDCR25D00000010 and/or
70CDCR25FR0000039. 

2. A copy of all written communications between ICE and CoreCivic pertaining to the records listed in Item 1 above for the period beginning March 1, 2024, and continuing through the date the agency tasks an adequate search responsive to this request.

3. A copy of all facility inspections ICE or any entity acting on ICE's behalf performed of the California City Immigrant Processing Center to ascertain the condition of the facility and whether it comports with federal standards, as well as any working papers created as part of these inspections and any communications between ICE and CoreCivic or any entity acting on ICE's behalf and CoreCivic pertaining to these inspections. 

4. A copy of all invoices CoreCivic sent to ICE for pertaining to the contracts described in Item 1 above. 

5. A copy of the ICE-approved facility handbook for the California City Immigrant Processing Center. 

6. Any communications between ICE and California City officials regarding its plan to reopen the Cal City prison during the period beginning December 1, 2024, and continuing through the date the agency tasks an adequate search responsive to this request. 

7. Any communications or agreements between ICE and the US Marshals regarding collaboration, coordination, or assistance between the Marshals and ICE in helping CoreCivic reopen the Cal City Prison. 

An adequate search responsive to this request will task, at minimum, the ICE Office of Acquisition Management (OAQ), ICE Office of Detention Oversight (ODO), ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations, and ICE's Office of the Acting Director. 

I request expedited processing of this request pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e) and declare under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746 that the following statements in support of this request are true and correct to the best of my knowledge and understanding: 

1. I am a member of the media primarily engaged in information dissemination. My edited work has appeared in The Intercept, The Appeal, and the Atlanta Community Press Collective. 
2. There is an urgent need to inform the public of the contractual and oversight decisions ICE and CoreCivic have reached regarding the Cal City prison facility. 
3. At present, contrary to its existing practice and obligations under federal appropriations requirements and the affirmative disclosure provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. 552(a)(2), ICE has not posted a copy of its contract with CoreCivic for the operation of the Cal City prison facility. See www.ice.gov/FOIA/library (generating no results for contracts pertaining to Cal City). 
4. At present, contrary to its existing practice and obligations under federal appropriations requirements and the affirmative disclosure provisions of FOIA, ICE has not posted a copy of any inspection it conducted for the Cal City prison. 
5. At present, contrary to its existing practice and obligations under federal appropriations requirements and the affirmative disclosure provisions of FOIA, ICE has not listed any detention statistics for the Cal City prison in its August 29, 2025, Detention Statistics disclosure, despite confirmed reports that ICE transferred noncitizens to the facility up to a week prior to releasing those figures. 
6. The Cal City prison is currently operating without a valid business license. 
7. The Cal City prison failed the pre-licensing fire inspection, and was deemed to dangerous to safely conduct business. 
8. The Cal City prison is currently operating without a valid Conditional Use Permit. 
9. The Cal City prison is currently operating in contravention of SB29, a California statute, CoreCivic and ICE challenged and lost the fight to strike down at the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Consequently, ICE and CoreCivic are violating the mandate in that case by operating Cal City in contravention of SB29. 
10. Conditions inside the Cal City prison are unconstitutionally punitive, according to reports from noncitizens currently housed there, in violation of the Ninth Circuit's King v. Los Angeles County. Detained immigrants transferred to the facility from other sites of ICE detention report being subjected to prison-like conditions of confinement, punitive searches, denial of medication, and lack of access to basic, legally required services, such as a law library and outdoor recreation. 
11. The location of the Cal City prison makes it particularly risky to transfer noncitizens there for detention who share certain genetic phenotypes because of their susceptibility and lack of immunity to Valley Fever, placing medically vulnerable detained immigrants at heightened risk for serious harm, and imposing serious strains on the local health and emergency response system. 
12. The Cal City prison was a site of multiple preventable deaths during CoreCivic's prior operation pursuant contracts with the California Department of Correction and Rehabilitation, including multiple drug overdoses, and prior to that, when the facility was being used by the Marshals and ICE, at least three apparent deaths in custody by people held there on ICE detainers.
13. The secrecy with which ICE and CoreCivic carried out the reopening of the facility has left immigrants and their advocates and attorneys unable to effectively ensure access to counsel and their loved ones. For instance, during a recent California City Planning Commission meeting on September 2, a young child named Monica called in to beg for information about her father's whereabouts. A mother, speaking through an interpreter, related how her son's transfer to the Cal City facility substantially interfered with her ability to assist him in preparing his defense before immigration court. 
14. CoreCivic has an exceptionally dangerous, deadly, and abusive track record in its performance of ICE detention services under contracts with ICE. Since ICE began publishing data on deaths in custody, CoreCivic-run facilities have seen more deaths, more findings of preventable death, and more repeat findings of violations, than other contractors. CoreCivic-run facilities top the list of deadliest detention sites in the ICE system, despite having no greater population than comparable facilities operated by the company's competitors. 
15. CoreCivic is subject to a nationwide, certified, forced labor class action in the Southern District of California that survived Supreme Court review and is proceeding toward summary judgment. It is unlawful for ICE to enter into contracts with firms that engage in forced labor.
16. There has been exceptional and widespread media interest in the reopening of the Cal City prison, and, based on the violations of law, standards, and policy listed above, there exists significant doubt as to the legality of the government's actions in awarding this contract under current circumstances. Examples of this coverage include, but are not limited to: 
1. https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/dolores-huerta-foundation-accuses-ice-center-of-operating-illegally-in-california-city
2. https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/california-city-ice-detention-center-sparks-controversy-at-planning-meeting

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

title: COOG Policies on Complaint-Forwarding of FOIL Violations

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: COOG Policies on Complaint-Forwarding of FOIL Violations
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

This request is submitted to clarify whether the Committee on Open Government (COOG) maintains any internal policies or records regarding the forwarding of credible evidence of willful concealment or destruction of public records (as described in Public Officers Law § 89(8) and Penal Law § 240.65) to enforcement authorities such as the State Inspector General, county district attorneys, the State Comptroller’s Investigations Division, or the Attorney General’s Public Integrity Bureau.

The Committee has stated that it lacks “enforcement” or “referral” authority. This request does not dispute that point. Instead, it seeks to determine whether COOG has adopted any policy—formal or informal—concerning whether staff may transmit neutral, fact-only complaints or notices when they encounter such conduct in FOIL appeals and determinations that agencies are required by law to forward to COOG (§ 89(4)(a)).

The purpose of this request is to ensure transparency: either to confirm that no such policy exists (meaning COOG has discretion but chooses not to act), or to identify any written guidance that explains why complaint-forwarding is prohibited. In either case, the public has an interest in understanding how systemic FOIL violations are handled when they rise to the level of potential criminal conduct.


Records sought (Jan. 1, 2020–present):

A. Any written policy, SOP, memo, training slide, or email guidance adopted or used by COOG that addresses whether COOG staff may (or may not) transmit complaints, notices, or factual summaries to

(i) the State Inspector General
(ii) county district attorneys
(iii) the Office of the State Comptroller Investigations
 or (iv) the Attorney General Public Integrity Bureau

concerning potential willful concealment or destruction of FOIL‑responsive records.

B. Any records reflecting instances in which COOG transmitted (or declined to transmit) such complaints/notices to any of the authorities in A.

C. Any legal analysis produced for or held by COOG that interprets FOIL §§ 89(1)(b), 89(2)(a), 89(4)(a) and/or Penal Law § 240.65 in relation to COOG’s ability to forward factual materials to enforcement authorities.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jackson Parker

title: FOIA Request – Records Concerning May 2025 Rare Breed Settlement Agreement on Forced Reset Triggers

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Request – Records Concerning May 2025 Rare Breed Settlement Agreement on Forced Reset Triggers
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, I request copies of all records created, received, or maintained by OLC from May 15, 2025, to the present concerning or referencing the May 2025 settlement agreement between the United States and Rare Breed Triggers regarding forced reset triggers (FRTs).

Specifically, please include:
	1.	Legal Opinions or Memoranda – Any formal or informal memoranda, legal analyses, or opinions prepared by OLC regarding the Rare Breed settlement and its implications for firearms classification or ATF enforcement policy.
	2.	Interagency Communications – Communications between OLC and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF), or any DOJ components, regarding the settlement’s legal effect or potential use in enforcement matters.
	3.	Policy Guidance – Any records where OLC provided advice, clearance, or recommendations concerning whether the settlement agreement may serve as precedent or guidance in enforcement matters involving other entities.

Format

Please provide records in electronic PDF format by email or secure download link.

Segregable Portions

If records contain exempt material, please release all reasonably segregable non-exempt portions.

Fees

I agree to pay fees up to $100. If costs will exceed this, please contact me before processing.

Expedited Processing

Requested under 28 C.F.R. § 16.5(e)(1)(iv), because this concerns government activity of significant public interest — DOJ’s role in establishing precedent through private settlement agreements.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Coleman Winthorpe

title: FOIA Request – Records Relating to the Rare Breed Settlement and Use in Enforcement Actions

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Request – Records Relating to the Rare Breed Settlement and Use in Enforcement Actions
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

This is a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552.

I request copies of all records created, sent, or received between May 15, 2025, and the present that meet the following criteria:
	1.	Internal ATF Guidance or Directives
	•	Any memoranda, field bulletins, internal emails, or policy documents distributed to ATF personnel (including Industry Operations Investigators) that reference or discuss the May 2025 settlement agreement concerning forced reset triggers and its implications for firearms enforcement.
	2.	Use in Subsequent Matters
	•	Any records that reference the above-mentioned settlement agreement in connection with other firearms-related inspections, enforcement actions, or compliance matters involving any entity or individual other than the parties to that settlement.
	3.	Communications with Other Agencies
	•	Any communications between ATF and the Department of Justice or other federal agencies discussing the settlement agreement’s impact on agency enforcement approach to forced reset triggers.

Expedited Processing Request

I request expedited processing under 28 C.F.R. § 16.5(e)(1)(iv) because the information requested has an urgency to inform the public concerning actual or alleged Federal Government activity—specifically, ATF’s use of a private legal settlement to establish enforcement precedent affecting lawful firearms owners and manufacturers.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Coleman Winthorpe

title: New York City's Domestic Worker Mediation Program

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Information on New York City's Domestic Worker Mediation Program, including answers to the following questions:

1. How does the program define "domestic workers"?
2. The DCWP website states: "If you are a paid care worker in NYC, you have a dedicated City resource for workplace questions and complaints: the Paid Care Division within the Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP) Office of Labor Policy & Standards." Then the website goes on to define paid care workers as including both homecare and domestic workers. Does this mean that homecare workers cannot seek dispute resolution under the program?
3. Why did Mayor Adams choose to launch this program?
4. If homecare workers cannot seek mediation under the program, is there another way for them to receive support from the DCWP?
5. How do domestic workers access the program? Is there a way to file a specific request for mediation? Or does the DCWP or another department identify potential cases in need of mediation from a general intake form for workers' complaints?
6. Can you confirm the date that the program went live? Was it December 6, 2022 (the publication date of this press release from Mayor Eric Adams' office)?
7. How many complaints has the program received from the time of launch until today? Can you share both the total and an annual breakdown?
8. What percent and gross number of complaints were filed by homecare workers, such as home health aides, personal care aides, and home attendants? Can you share the breakdown of complaints by category of occupation?
9. What percent of complaints are filed by women?
10. What percent of complaints are filed by immigrants?
11. What is the average age of the complainants?
12. Were there any cases filed by employers? Or does the program take cases that are filed by workers?
13. What percent and gross number of complaints filed were about wage theft? Can you share a breakdown of complaints by complaint type?
14. What are the types of outcomes that can result from a case submitted for mediation under the program?
15. What does "resolution" mean under the program? 
16. Does "resolution" include wage recovery in wage theft cases? If so, what percent and gross amount of owed wages were returned to the workers on average?
17. Can you provide an end-to-end overview of the steps in the process, from intake to outcome?
18. Of the total number of complaints filed from launch until today, how many have been selected for mediation under the program?
19. Of the total number of complaints selected for mediation from launch until today, how many were resolved?
20. Are workers who seek resolution through the program still able to pursue litigation? Or does participation in the program prevent them from doing so?
21. How is DCWP or other offices (the Mayor's office, OATH) spreading awareness of the program, if at all?
22. What is the budget for the program?
23. Is DCWP aware of any cases of employer retaliation against workers who seek support from the program?
24. Are there any other programs by the state or city that provide similar or overlapping services?

Where possible, I'd appreciate any spreadsheets you can provide for analysis as well.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Reva Abrol

title: 9/11 Records

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: 9/11 Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I'm looking for records related to the events of September 11, 2001. Specifically the following:

1). All records pertaining to the property records of 'Flight 93' crash site, including any deeds, contracts, agreements, easements, written communications, and anything involving the owners which would include the surface owners Svonavec Inc. and easement/ coal mining rights to PBS Coals Inc., Mincorp Acquisitions Inc., and Citigroup. 

2). All photographs and video taken of 'Flight 93' crash site from the ground and air between September 11, 2001 and October 31, 2002.

Additionally, all photographs and video taken of the separate debris and debris fields at Indian Lake, PA and New Baltimore, PA between September 11, 2001 and October 31, 2002.


3). All records, such as, chain of custody logs, communications, document/ photography records, and current possession of 'Flight 93' debris that was located around Indian Lake, PA as indicated in The Daily American Fri, Sep 14, 2001 ·Page 12 where FBI Crowley speaks that on behalf of the investigation. John Fleegle is a local resident also mentioned in the same article that evidence was given to the FBI that was collected from Indian Lake. 

4). All records, such as, chain of custody logs, communications, document/ photography records, and current possession of 'Flight 93' debris that was located around New Baltimore, PA as indicated in Pittsburgh Post-Gazette Fri, Sep 14, 2001 ·Page 11 where FBI Crowley speaks that on behalf of the investigation. Andy Stoe, a local resident, also mentioned in the article that evidence of debris being scrap paper, an endorsed check, financial statements. On the Lowery Farm there was debris of financial documents scatter that were given to the FBI. In the Dayton Daily News Fri, Sep 14, 2001 Page 6, a local resident Melanie Hankinson found debris consisting of financial documents, an airline magazine, pilot handbook, and a few other stuff all confirmed by Agent Crowley of the FBI.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Charles Kallas

title: FBI RECORDS MONTY MASSIMI

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: FBI RECORDS MONTY MASSIMI
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation into Monty V. (Valentino) Massimi. 

Monty's DOD is April 3, 2007.  See: https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/buffalonews/name/monty-massimi-obituary?id=4686304 ... Also see: https://buffalonews.newspapers.com/article/the-buffalo-news-monty-massimi-obituary/148697516/

Monty is the son of Willis (AKA William, AKA Billy) V. Massimi and Joal Massimi who were married on 4/23/1960 and divorced in 1972.  See: https://buffalonews.newspapers.com/article/the-buffalo-news-monty-massimis-mother/180313982/

Willis Massimi's DOD was February 26, 2013.  See: https://buffalonews.newspapers.com/article/the-buffalo-news-obituary-for-willis-mas/180314346/  See also: https://buffalonews.com/obituaries/article_133442a6-951c-5138-865c-b4597cb04538.html

Please include any any all references to Monty's father Willis Massimi. 

Monty lived at the following addresses:
197 Lovering Ave, Buffalo, NY 14216
112 School St, Buffalo, NY 46213
4250 Ridge Lea Rd, Buffalo, NY 14226
860 Niagara Street, Buffalo, NY 46213
He also maintained a residence in Lockport, NY

Monty was murdered by Salvatore "Sam" M. Vacanti at Jacobi Restaurant.
See: https://buffalonews.newspapers.com/article/the-buffalo-news-monty-massimi-shot/148744554/
See Also: https://buffalonews.newspapers.com/article/the-buffalo-news-sam-vacanti-arrested-fo/148744717/
See Also: https://buffalonews.newspapers.com/article/the-buffalo-news-sam-vacantis-bail-revo/148744889/
For Police Report See Also: https://cdn.muckrock.com/foia_files/2022/06/29/vacanti.pdf

Additionally, Monty was close with LCN Figures:

1. Frank "Butch" BiFulco (Buffalo LCN Family). BiFulco's DOD is October 12, 2020. See: https://buffalonews.com/obituaries/frank-butch-bifulco-75-reputed-mobster-with-a-brilliant-mind/article_1165f678-1ab8-11eb-a55c-130105cb65b9.html See also: https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/buffalonews/name/frank-bifulco-obituary?id=4880120

2. Vincent "Jimmy" Caci (Los Angelos  LCN  Family). Caci's DOD is August 16, 2011. See: https://buffalonews.com/obituaries/caci-vincent-d-jimmy/article_af51bceb-59cd-581c-9ed9-ac04a187523a.html See also: https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/buffalonews/name/vincent-caci-obituary?id=4763396. Attached is a picture of Monty Massimi with Vincent "Jimmy" Caci

3. Stephen Cino (Los Angelos LCN Family). Cino's DOD is March 11. 2013. See: https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/lvrj/name/stephen-cino-obituary?id=20533344

4. Anthony "Tony" Alessi (Buffalo LCN Family). Alessi's DOD is June 19, 2008. See: https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/buffalonews/name/anthony-alessi-obituary?id=4699991

5. Frank "Babe" Mambrino (Buffalo LCN Family). Frank Mambrino's DOD is October 11, 2001. See: https://buffalonews.newspapers.com/article/the-buffalo-news-frank-mambrino-son-of-c/167281604/

6. John "Eyes" Mambrino (Buffalo LCN Family). John Mambrino's DOD is January 4, 2015. See: https://buffalonews.newspapers.com/article/the-buffalo-news-obituary-for-john-a-ma/167281899/

Please conduct a search for the above referenced records at the FBI Field Office in Buffalo, NY.

In addition to conducting this search for records at the FBI Field Office in Buffalo, NY, please conduct an additional search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to :

A. The Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, 
B. The Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, 
C. The Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and 
D. The Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices.

Check the Buffalo FBI field office, the Central Records System, and these above referenced indices for:
A. Both main-file records and 
B. Cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies at FBI Headquarters. 

Please also conduct a search for records at the Alexandria Records Center. 

If any potentially responsive records have been destroyed and/or transferred to NARA, then I request copies of the destruction or transfer slips as well as any other documentation relating to, mentioning or describing said transfer or destruction, to include but not be limited to confirmation that the Bureau has no other copies of said records. 

If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Mob

title: IHSC Folkston 911 SENs/SIRs

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: IHSC Folkston 911 SENs/SIRs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All Significant Event Notifications and Significant Incident Reports received by the IHSC Field Medical Coordinator or OAQ Contracting Officer pertaining to medical emergencies or 911 calls at the Folkston ICE Processing Center, and Annex, for the period beginning January 1, 2024, and continuing through September 3, 2025. 

I request expedited processing of this request pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e) and declare the following statements in support thereof to be true and correct under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746: 

1. Folkston is now the largest ICE detention facility in Georgia. 
2. Following the preventable death of Jaspal Singh in 2023, ICE rewarded Folkston's operator, GEO, with an expansion of the Folkston contract worth over $100M
3. In 2025, Folkston was the site of a second in-custody death. 
4. Logs of 911 calls reflect instances in which EMS units were unavailable to gain timely access to the facility as a result of GEO staff's inability to consistently man the sally ports and entryways to secure areas, delaying emergency care for people inside. 
5. Lack of access to timely emergency medical care threatens the health safety of people in Folkston and the surrounding community. 
6. ICE Mortality Reviewers have attributed lack of timely access to emergency medical care to a significant number of deaths in ICE custody. 
7. The records requested will shed light on whether, and to what extent, ICE is aware of the challenges posed and consequences created by its use of detention in high numbers at the Folkston facility. 
8. I am a member of the media primarily engaged in information dissemination through edited publications, and have previously been granted expedited processing by federal FOIA offices on this basis. 
9. These records are needed on an expedited basis to fill out the federal side of a piece for which I have received journalism grant funding and which will be published no later than October.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.subject: Police Records Request :: W725891-090425
communications.communication:
Dear Adam  Steinbaugh: 
 
 
Thank you for your interest in public records of the City of San Antonio. Your request has been received and is being processed in accordance with Chapter 552 of Texas Government Code, the Public Information Act. Your request was received in this office on 9/4/2025 and given the reference number W725891-090425 for tracking purposes. 
 
 
Your request will be forwarded to the relevant City department(s). You will be contacted about the availability and/or provided with copies of the records in question. 
 
In accordance with the Public Information Act, Chapter 552 of the Texas Government Code, the City of San Antonio makes all of its public records available to citizens. 
 
The Public Information Act does not require governmental bodies to create new information, perform legal research, or to answer questions. The request must ask for records or information already in existence. The City of San Antonio will not comply with a standing request for information to be collected or prepared in the future. 
 
The City of San Antonio will respond within ten business days following submission of requests. The City of San Antonio may collect a fee as prescribed by law for the requested documents. For more information on the Texas Public Information Act, please visit the Texas Attorney General Web site at www.oag.state.tx.us/open/og_faqs.shtml. 
 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. Again, thank you for using the Open Records Center. 
 
 
 
Notice: 
 
The City’s AD 1.31 was signed on December 12, 2024. The City informed the Office of the Attorney General of the update on January 9, 2025. The City will implement the changes starting January 21, 2025. 
1. Texas Government Code Section 552.234(c) (the Texas Public Information Act) allows a governmental body to designate one mailing address and one electronic mail address for receiving written requests for public information. The City of San Antonio Administrative Directive 1.31, entitled Open Government, now provides the following methods to requestors seeking records from the City: 
a. Via email: openrecords@sanantonio.gov 
b. Via the open government portal: https://sanantonio.govqa.us/webapp/_rs/(S(nzhdsq2jtkns5hfojy5kcmbj))/supporthome.aspx (http:) 
c. By mail to the City: Open Records Division of the City of San Antonio, P.O. Box 839966, San Antonio, Texas 78283. 
d. By mail to San Antonio Police Department: 315 S. Santa Rosa, San Antonio, Texas 78207. 
e. By mail to San Antonio Fire Department: 315 S. Santa Rosa, San Antonio, Texas 78207. 
f. Note, hand-delivery and in-person requests are permitted under the Act. 
2. The City is not required to respond to a written request for public information unless the request is received by one of the methods listed above (Texas Government Code Section 552.205).

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: R014698-090425
communications.communication:
Dear Adam Steinbaugh: 
Thank you for your interest in public records of District of Columbia. Your request has been received and is being processed. Your request was received in this office on 9/4/2025 and given the reference number R014698-090425 for tracking purposes. 
In all future correspondence regarding this request, please reference request number R014698-090425. You can monitor the progress of your request in the " My Records Center". 
 
The District of Columbia is required to respond to your FOIA request within fifteen (15) business days of its receipt.  See D.C. Official Code § 2-532(c)(2011).  However, under certain circumstances, D.C. Official Code § 2-532(d)(2011) authorizes the District to extend, by ten (10) additional days, the deadline by which it must respond to a FOIA request.  One of the circumstances provided by that statute is a case in which the District needs additional time to search for, collect and examine voluminous amounts of records and/or consult with an additional D.C. agency. 
For any questions regarding your request, please contact the FOIA office directly. Find the list of agency Open Government and FOIA contact information by visiting FOIA Contact Information. For ease of reference, we ask that you have your FOIA Reference Number available when you contact the FOIA office. 
Regards, 
District of Columbia

Thank you for your interest in public records of Boston Police Department. Your request has been received and is being processed. Your request was received in this office on 9/4/2025 11:02:06 PM and given the reference number B002484-090425 for tracking purposes. 
If this is a media request, please contact the Office of Media Relations directly at 617.343.4520. 
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any materials or programming (including handouts, slideshows, videos, textbooks, or other media) used in connection with providing training or guidance to law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the following subjects: (a) The First Amendment; (b) protests or demonstrations; (c) freedom of speech or expression; (d) filming police officers. This request is limited to materials used in trainings since January 1, 2020.

2. Any policy concerning whether trainings on the topics mentioned in (1) are mandatory, or regulating the frequency of such trainings.

3. A copy of any document sufficient to show the most recent training conducted for law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the subjects in (1). For example, this could be a receipt or contract for an outside vendor or speaker, or it could be a dated sign-in sheet from the training.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: First Amendment Trainings for Law-Enforcement Officers (Suffolk County Police Department)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: First Amendment Trainings for Law-Enforcement Officers (Suffolk County Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any materials or programming (including handouts, slideshows, videos, textbooks, or other media) used in connection with providing training or guidance to law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the following subjects: (a) The First Amendment; (b) protests or demonstrations; (c) freedom of speech or expression; (d) filming police officers. This request is limited to materials used in trainings since January 1, 2020.

2. Any policy concerning whether trainings on the topics mentioned in (1) are mandatory, or regulating the frequency of such trainings.

3. A copy of any document sufficient to show the most recent training conducted for law-enforcement officers in your agency with respect to any of the subjects in (1). For example, this could be a receipt or contract for an outside vendor or speaker, or it could be a dated sign-in sheet from the training.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: UMaine U

communications.subject: Maine Freedom of Access Act Request: UMaine U
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maine Freedom of Access Act, I hereby request the following records:

All electronic communications between Senator Susan Collins and/or representatives of her office and members of the University President and her cabinet. The purpose of this request is to elucidate an elected official's actions leading up to the recent congressional spending bill passed in July and its effects on the University of Maine. 

In order to narrow this search, please query the email addresses of Jenny Boyden, Kody Varahramyan, James S. Ward IV, Jeffery Mills, Gabriel Paquette, Nicole Lawrence, John Diamond, Kevin Coughlin, and Jenny Boyden, for the following strings: "Susan Collins", "Senator Collins", "Sen. Collins" in addition to any emails containing the domain "@mail.house.gov". Additionally, please limit your search to the inclusive range of 5/1/25-7/30/25.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by 1 M.R.S.A. § 408(6). The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Daniel Boguslaw

communications.subject: Re: Maine Freedom of Access Act Request: UMaine U
communications.communication:

I am writing to acknowledge your Maine Freedom of Access (FOAA) request
dated September 2, 2025. This email will serve as the 5 working day
confirmation of your request under 1 MRSA §408-A(3).



Research and collection of records responsive to your request are currently

like to further clarify the scope of your request or have any additional
questions, please do not hesitate to reach out.
Regards,



Mary Pettegrow

Paralegal

Office of the General Counsel

University of Maine System

title: ALPR Audit Metadata Records FOIA (Skokie Police Department)

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: ALPR Audit Metadata Records FOIA (Skokie Police Department)
communications.communication:
Re: ALPR Audit Metadata Records FOIA

To the Skokie Police Department FOIA Officer,

This request is made under the provisions of Illinois Freedom of Information Act. for the following records:

1. All Flock Safety ALPR “Organization Audit” and “Network Audit” records logged between January 1, 2024, and the date this request is processed where the “Reason” field contains any of the following terms (case-insensitive):

“Immigration”
“ICE”
“HSI”
“Homeland Security”
“DHS”
“usbp”

2. All Flock Safety ALPR “Network Audit” records logged between January 1, 2024, and the date this request is processed where the “Org Name” field contains any of the following terms (case-insensitive):

“U.S. Border Patrol” or “US Border Patrol [Federal]”
“Palos Heights IL PD”
“Johnson County TX SO“
“Texas Department of Public Safety”

Both the “Organization Audit” and “Network Audit” are available within the Insights tab of the Flock Safety system. Please redact in full the “License Plate” column, I am not requesting that data. The agency may redact or omit that column in its entirety. The remaining fields requested such as Name, Org Name, Reason, and Search Time consist solely of administrative metadata documenting system use. 

Clarifications Regarding Scope and Burden

Not burdensome: 
This request is narrowly tailored. It does not seek every audit entry, only those containing the short list of immigration-related keywords. While there may be many more terms and variations used for immigration searches, we are keeping this list short and explicit to avoid a burdensome request. The requested records are produced automatically by the Flock Safety system in spreadsheet form. Filtering the “Reason” column for a limited set of keywords is a routine data filtering operation. 

Not categorical: 
This request is narrowly tailored. It seeks only those audit entries where the “Reason” field contains any of the specific immigration-related terms provided in the short list above. It does not encompass all audit records or broad categories of data.

Not exempt under § 2-130: 
Audit logs are administrative records documenting system use,  such as the identity of the user, the time of access, and the stated reason for the search. With the exception of the “License Plate” column (which can be omitted), these logs do not fall within the statutory definition of “ALPR information” under 625 ILCS 5/2-130. They are oversight metadata, not raw surveillance outputs.

Compelling public interest:
The Illinois TRUST Act (5 ILCS 805) and the Way Forward Act (Public Act 102-0234) explicitly prohibit local law enforcement from engaging in federal civil immigration enforcement.

625 ILCS 5/2-130 restricts the use of ALPR systems for immigration enforcement and limits secrecy around ALPR oversight.

The Illinois Secretary of State has launched a statewide investigation into ALPRs, including how they are used for immigration criminalization*. This underscores the importance of these public audit records and the clear public interest in disclosing the requested records.

Some recent public reporting on local ALPRs includes:

ICE Taps into Nationwide AI-Enabled Camera Network, Data Shows
<https://web.archive.org/web/20250527141200/https://www.404media.co/ice-taps-into-nationwide-ai-enabled-camera-network-data-shows/>

DEA agent used Illinois cop’s Flock license plate reader password for immigration enforcement searches
<https://web.archive.org/web/20250811191507/https://unraveledpress.com/a-dea-agent-used-an-illinois-police-officers-flock-license-plate-reader-password-for-unauthorized-immigration-enforcement-searches/>

Feds Used Local Cop's Password to Do Immigration Surveillance With Flock Cameras
<https://web.archive.org/web/20250812151424/https://www.404media.co/feds-used-local-cops-password-to-do-immigration-surveillance-with-flock-cameras/>

CBP Had Access to More than 80,000 Flock AI Cameras Nationwide
<https://web.archive.org/web/20250902190711/https://www.404media.co/cbp-had-access-to-more-than-80-000-flock-ai-cameras-nationwide/>

Flock Safety license plate camera company stops cooperating with federal agencies over investigation concerns
<https://web.archive.org/web/20250902193429/https://www.cbsnews.com/chicago/news/flock-safety-license-plate-company-federal-agencies-cooperation/>

Finally, it is important to note that the very data being withheld from the public is already uploaded in full to a private data broker, where it is stored in proprietary off-site systems and made available to Flock Safety system users. This practice constitutes an enclosure of public data collected without the consent of those targeted by municipal surveillance weapons. The public interest is evident and the request is clearly within the scope of FOIA.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you for your assistance. I anticipate your response within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,
Niles Coalition

Footnotes:

*Giannoulias Cracks Down on Unlawful Use of License Plate Reader Data
<https://web.archive.org/web/20250702121007/https://www.ilsos.gov/news/2025/june/250612d1.pdf>

*Giannoulias’ Audit Finds License Plate Reader Company in Violation of State Law
<https://web.archive.org/web/20250902182146/https://www.ilsos.gov/news/2025/august/250825d1.pdf>

Not exempt under § 2-130: 
Audit logs are administrative records documenting system use, such as the identity of the user, the time of access, and the stated reason for the search. With the exception of the “License Plate” column (which can be omitted), these logs do not fall within the statutory definition of “ALPR information” under 625 ILCS 5/2-130. They are oversight metadata, not raw surveillance outputs. 

Compelling public interest: 
The Illinois TRUST Act (5 ILCS 805) and the Way Forward Act (Public Act 102-0234) explicitly prohibit local law enforcement from engaging in federal civil immigration enforcement. 

625 ILCS 5/2-130 restricts the use of ALPR systems for immigration enforcement and limits secrecy around ALPR oversight. 

The Illinois Secretary of State has launched a statewide investigation into ALPRs, including how they are used for immigration criminalization*. This underscores the importance of these public audit records and the clear public interest in disclosing the requested records.
